prompt: Please write an operative note for a 52 year old male referred by O'Connor. The patient has stenosis of the left upper lobe. We found blood-tinged mucus and fibrotic scarring and concentric stenosis causing 70% narrowing. We did BAL, biopsy, cryotherapy, and dilated with a Mustang 6/7/8 to 6 mm and 7 mm. The airway was 100% at the end.
completion:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: February 9, 2026 CC Referred Physician: O'Connor

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 52-year-old male who presents with bronchial stenosis of the left upper lobe (LUL).

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE
Therapeutic aspiration, initial episode (31645) 
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) (31624) 
Endobronchial Biopsy(s) (31625) 
Balloon dilation (31630) 
Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (e.g., cryotherapy) (31641) 

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS Minimum 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).

Initial Airway Inspection The endotracheal tube was in good position.
The visualized portion of the trachea was of normal caliber and the carina was sharp.
The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level.

Findings: The airway exam was notable for mildly tortuous airways as before, with intact anastomoses bilaterally.
Mild secretions were noted bilaterally, with blood-tinged mucus emanating from the LUL.

Stenosis: The LUL orifice was approximately 70% narrowed with a combination of fibrotic scarring and concentric stenosis.

Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Bronchus and LUL Carina from mucus and mucus plugs.

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the LUL. The lesion was successfully removed. Samples were sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal).

Balloon Dilation Balloon dilation was performed at the LUL.
A Mustang 4mm balloon was used to perform dilation to 4 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).
A Mustang 6/7/8 balloon was subsequently used to perform dilation to 6 mm and 7 mm at the LUL (2 inflations, 60 seconds each).

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction (Cryotherapy) Endobronchial obstruction at the LUL was treated with cryotherapy.

Modality: Cryoprobe (1.7mm probe) 
Setting: 30-second freeze-thaw cycles 
Result: Ablation performed.

Prior to treatment, the affected airway was noted to be 30% patent. After treatment, the airway was 100%.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at the LUL.
Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 15 cc of NS.
Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMENS
LUL EBBx (micro) 
LUL BAL 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
52-year-old male with bronchial stenosis of the LUL.
Ongoing recurrence of stenosis; surveillance for stent restenosis.
Will need ongoing close vigilance of the airway due to tendency to fuse shut.
Follow-up BAL results.
Repeat bronchoscopy in 2 weeks for dilation.

Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

Mild secretions were noted bilaterally, with tenacious white secretions emanating from the RUL.

Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 15 cc of NS.
Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMENS
LLL EBBx (micro) 
LLL BAL 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
66-year-old female with bronchial stenosis of the LLL.
Ongoing recurrence of stenosis; surveillance for stent restenosis.
Will need ongoing close vigilance of the airway due to tendency to fuse shut.
Follow-up BAL results.
Repeat bronchoscopy in 2 weeks for dilation.
